column8: Amazing Sunset Experience at Galle Fort Lighthouse
column11: One of the highlights of our trip with Hai Sri Lanka Tours was the evening visit to Galle Fort Lighthouse. Our guide, Sithum, took us there perfectly timed for the sunset, and it was truly magical. Watching the sun set over the ocean, with the historic fort as the backdrop, was an unforgettable experience. Sithum made the visit even more special by sharing fascinating stories about the fort’s history, its architecture, and the surrounding area. He ensured that we had plenty of time to take in the views, capture photos, and soak in the atmosphere without feeling rushed.not too crowded. The combination of stunning scenery, historical significance, and Sithum’s knowledgeable guidance made this part of the tour absolutely memorable. I highly recommend this experience to anyone visiting Sri Lanka it’s the perfect way to end a day filled with exploration and adventure.

Welcome to the Galle Dutch Fort Lighthouse, one of the most iconic landmarks within the historic Galle Fort! As your guide, I’m excited to share the fascinating history and beauty of this picturesque lighthouse, which has been a beacon for sailors navigating the southern coast of Sri Lanka for over a century. Standing at 26.5 meters tall, the Galle Lighthouse was originally built by the British in 1848, making it Sri Lanka’s oldest lighthouse. Though the original structure was destroyed by fire, it was rebuilt in 1939 and continues to operate today, guiding ships safely to the Galle harbor. Its white cylindrical tower stands in striking contrast to the azure waters of the Indian Ocean, creating a postcard-perfect view. What makes this lighthouse particularly special is its location within the Galle Dutch Fort, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Walking around the lighthouse, you’re surrounded by colonial-era architecture, cobblestone streets, and the ancient fort walls—all of which tell the story of Sri Lanka’s colonial past. The combination of maritime history and cultural heritage here is truly unique. The best time to visit is early morning or late afternoon when the golden light illuminates the lighthouse and the sea beyond. From here, you’ll enjoy sweeping views of the coastline, and if you’re lucky, you might even spot a few ships in the distance. Galle Lighthouse is not just a functional maritime structure but a symbol of the rich history and beauty that defines the Galle Fort. Whether you’re a history enthusiast, a photography lover, or just someone looking to enjoy the scenic views, this is a must-see attraction during your visit to Sri Lanka. I hope you enjoy this perfect blend of history, architecture, and natural beauty at the Galle Dutch Fort Lighthouse!

Galle, a city and port in the southwest of Sri Lanka, which is the capital of the Southern Province, became known to Europeans after the first visit to the area by the Portuguese in 1505. In fact, the history of this settlement goes back hundreds of years - it’s not for nothing that some researchers identify Halle with the Old Testament city of Tarshish, from which the well-known King Solomon actively “pumped out” sapphires, rubies, topazes, amethysts, etc. (it’s not for nothing that in ancient times Ceylon was called Ratna-Dwipa, which means “Island of Precious Stones”) and the tusks of the unfortunate elephants... Perhaps these are all legends, but on Ptolemy’s world map, dating back to 125-150 AD, this city is already present.!!! There are more than enough attractions here - Galle is considered one of the main centers of tourism in Sri Lanka, and the local fort has been recognized as a world heritage and included in the list of cultural heritage sites of the UNESCO World Heritage Site. My current post is a continuation of the “lighthouse line” of seaside lights of the island. Yes, yes, in Galle I found another lighthouse - Galle Fort Lighthouse. And this building, as follows from its very name, is not just a lighthouse, but an element of a fortification - the ancient Galle Fort, built by the Portuguese back in 1588!!! If you admire the Galle Fort from a bird's eye view, then, like the author of these lines, “take your hat off” to the fortification geniuses who designed this defensive facility. It was on the southeastern cape, on which the fort was built, that in 1848 the then owners of Galle, the British (the latter chopped off the fort from the Dutch, and those from the Portuguese) built the first lighthouse. You can see his photographic image in the photo album of Frederick Fiebig, a photographer best known for his photographs of India, Sri Lanka, Mauritius, South Africa, taken in the 50s of the 19th century, kept as part of the collection of the Oriental and Indian Department of the British Library. I took the time to find an image of the forerunner of the Galle Fort Lighthouse from the British Library collection: it was a 24.4 meter high metal structure, built from material brought from England, designed by the British architect Alexander Gordon. The lighthouse, as a direct sea light, and also as an element of the defense of the Galle fort, was built in the southwestern corner of the fortification, on the western side of the Galle harbor, just on the fort’s fortress wall, as if at the “base” of the Utrecht Bastion. From its top, the approaches to Galle harbor were clearly visible, and the lantern was visible at a distance of 19 kilometers. Unfortunately, this building was destroyed in a fire in July 1936 (I can’t imagine how a metal thing could burn out!!!). What we see now and what I managed to capture was built in 1939, about a hundred meters from the site of the predecessor. The height of the current stone structure is 26.5 meters. Taking into account the age of its predecessor, the Galle Fort lighthouse is considered the oldest sea light in Sri Lanka (which is quite relative, in my humble opinion). From a distance, the white cone-shaped “body” of the lighthouse looked very attractive (despite the cloudy and stormy weather). Nearby is a shabby pillar, evoking thoughts about the frailty of all earthly things and the postulates of uncle Sigmund Freud. The “postulate” that was most “beaconed” was the washed underwear hung at the foot of the lighthouse (apparently from the lighthouse workers)... Don’t miss it!!!

Sitting on top of the Galle fort, marking one of the bay's endpoints (the other is the much more romantic Japanese Peace Pagoda, sits the Galle Fort lighthouse. There is nothing to do there, other than enjoying the view over the busy bay, which is a great sight, indeed. Easy to find. Plenty of restaurants within short walking distance.
Just another lighthouse but it's still functioning. The fort and esplanade surrounding the lighthouse makes it interesting and an easy landmark.

It is one of the highlights at Galle Fort, located at the tip of the land. The structure is well maintained and serves as a monument of the fort. The lighthouse is a structure which is not a common scene in this country, having it as part of the history adds up to the highlights. It is good to visit if anyone happens to be in this part of the country but for me I don't consider it a must-see, again this is a personal opinion and any tourist attraction depends on the interest of the visitor.
An imposing sight on the edge of the 17th century Galle Fort - a real landmark. We enjoyed walking around the exterior of the Lighthouse right next to the munitions store.
This is a nice pretty light house ..don't take any tours ...just stop the taxi for a while and some pics near the light house .. Worth a stop Water is crystal clean near this place
This has given an attraction to the Galle Fort. You must visit this place if you are in Galle Fort. This has been done in Dutch Era.
The lighthouse is a quality structure beautiful design and pleasant surroundings. Naturally right on the ocean and on the fort wall

While walking along the ramparts of the old town at Galle we came across this lighthouse on one promontory, clearly this was a great vantage point in previous times but we could not see how it was possible to access the lighthouse itself.  Nevertheless it was impressive & showed how the whole area was protected & ships warned

This is Sri Lanka's oldest light station[ and dates back to 1848,The current 26.5-metre-high  lighthouse was erected here in 1939. It is an impressive structure that still feels like it is protecting the Galle Harbour.
We walked past here and looked a lovely lighthouse. Not sure if you can climb up into it - we did not see anyone doing this

This lighthouse was erected in 1939 after the 1848 building was destroyed by fire in 1934. It is a UNESCO world heritage site and a popular tourist attraction - a favourite place for a memorable photograph. Be there early evening, if possible, the sunset in remarkable

Just an ordinary Light House in a Beautiful historical Dutch settlement in the Southern Tip of Sri Lanka You cannot miss this Light House even if you wanted to but a beautiful walk around the small bi-lanes lined with some beautiful old houses ib European Architectural Style that resembles small European cities and makes you forget you are in The Southern Tip of Sri Lanka

Again, if you’re in Galle then fine take a look and a walk around the Galle Fort but I would not recommend coming in from far and paying lots of money for a day trip to see it, it’s not worth it. Nothing in Galle is. Beach surround is nice to watch sunset but full of rubbish and plastic and wouldn’t recommend swimming in it.
It's just a light house , not a big attraction , so you cannot expect a lot of things from this location ,it's worth for taking photos here
very much attractive, there is a sea bathing place just down here, very much siutable for travel photoes,  on the top of the fort wall,

Very nice lighthouse.  Good for viewing sunset as well. There are many people there waiting to watch the beautiful sunset before moving to the lighthouse. You wil be amazed with the beautiful sunset and scenery that overlook the sea.
A very old structure, set up in the year 1938 by the Dutch. This is inside the Galle Fort. It is now defunct. A piece of history. The view of the bay is nice from this vantage point.

Well we actually went there for breakfast on our way to Wadduwa. And the spread was alright comparing to most hotels down south. And the view is magnificent from the restaurant. The Hotel I pictured in me was a much better version to be honest. But I guess the rooms and the view from it would give them the additional pluses. The breakfast was Rs 2000 per person. The restaurant staff were very friendly and efficient. And very welcoming!
Galle Fort Lighthouse is one of the must see landmarks at Galle Fort. It provides a simple but impressive backdrop to this Unesco heritage site.

Sitting on top of the Galle fort, marking one of the bay's endpoints (the other is the much more romantic Japanese Peace Pagoda, sits the Galle Fort lighouse. There is nothing to do there, other than enjoying the view over the busy bay, which is a great sight, indeed.
It is a nice piece of landmark within the fort itself. We just enjoyed taking a picture of it and walking by

A visit to Galle would not be complete without admiring it's imposing Lighthouse, particularly at around sunset time. Busloads of tourists and Sri Lankans alight to take photos with it, but few recall how it was battered during the 2004 Tsunami that wreaked havoc along much of Sri Lanka's coastline.

It is not possible to enter the lighthouse, but it is such a well known sight that it is just as rewarding to walk the ramparts to it taking in the views all around. It is alongside the Old Town and Fort area so it is possible visit these too, just make sure you allow enough time for everything; a minimum of three hours.

Located by the Galle Fort wall. History everywhere. Amazing sight day & night. Swim beach with rock pools in ocean so will suit young to old, lots of coral thongs will be useful. Easy to find. Plenty of restaurants within short walking distance.

As part of our trip to southern Sri Lanka we spent the afternoon in the Galle Fort district. A busy place with a historic feel and lovely buildings the area offered a pleasant distraction from the beach activities. Nice restaurant’s are spread through the area with nice views out to the coastline and the lighthouse. Thoroughly recommend an afternoon here enjoying the area.

Located in Galle - the lighthouse is one of many attractions at Galle (the other main attraction is the fort).  Recommend the 2.7km walking tour which is flat and easy for families.  Try and do the walk in the morning or late afternoon away from the heat of the day.  You can’t go inside the lighthouse, but the view is great and one of many things to visit at Galle. Just be aware that whilst only 100km from Colombo, it takes forever to get anywhere by car.  It took us 4 hours to get to Galle via the coastal road.  We were offered the option of the highway on the way back to Colombo - had we knows this was an option we would have skipped the coastal road.  The highway slashed our travel time by more than half and the toll was $4.

Situated inside the world heritage site of the Gale Fort. This feature makes up a small part if a big picture. The entire place is steeped in history, beauty and funky stuff. Just go you wont regret it ... and allow a daynor two to explore

We enjoyed both an evening and then a morning walk and went around the outside of the wall which didn’t take long and saw the two main gates and watchtower near the cricket ground then the lighthouse and the sea the other sides. Worth going to see. Such a lovely town to visit.

Galle is absolutely stunning, one of the nicest places we visited in the whole of Sri Lanka. The whole town is a gem but the ramparts are it's finest attribute and the Galle lighthouse dating from 1938 is probably it's most photographed and iconic spot. We didn't go up it, I don't even know if you can, rather we strolled along the ramparts and through the tight quaint streets of the fort, always seeming to end up back at this gorgeous lighthouse. It's a stunner!

This photographs very well and is part of the embedded character of Galle. Great walk around it. Worth looking up it’s history before going as it is very interesting. It has certainly saved and guided a lot of ships in its life.
Terrific place to give your kids a swim in a protected environment that is not too busy. Just out the front of the lighthouse. Check it out.
Nothing much to write home about. Just another light house really. Would have been great if there were a way to the top for a view of the setting Sun!

column11: Worth walking through the old town to get to this very pretty lighthouse. Makes a great photo op and you can swim nearby if you want to. You can’t go up it but it doesn’t hurt to have a look and takes you close to the old Dutch hospital.

Galle is quite expensive with its hipster cafes, so if you on a budget, i suggest get a couple of beers, sit down with your partner while enjoying this place!

The place is not accessible for the public for viewing purposes but, can be viewed from the outside. It’s right around the Galle Dutch shopping precinct. Great for a quick photo op. I would recommend visiting this place around the time of the sunset for a better experience. Other than that there is nothing much to see.

This lighthouse will be that it is very old and you can walk down the historical place. It is a must stop location for such an iconic lighthouse and a lovely place to pause on your walk around the walls of Galle. It is an ordinary lighthouse which is still functioning till today. But together with the surroundings, it makes a nice setting to take pictures in with a beautiful view of the sea beach. Lots of local families were there too as it was a weekend when we went. To select the time morning from 9 to 11 am or 3 to 5 pm as it would be comfortable. At 1 pm it was too sunny. Located at right on the beach which has very old trees for some respite from the heat.
A beauty of a building which adds to the rather flat skyline and with this and the way the palms dress the lighthouse up, it makes for some interesting photos.
We walked around Galle exploring the town and the lighthouse looks lovely on the shore. We just walked past and took a couple of pictures before exploring the main town.
At this place is a litle beach, where a lot of people use to swim in the hot water.  This is the perfect spot to enjoy the sunset.. at this place a lot of people enjoy the view..

nice place but closed. you cannot come up without supervisor allowance. very beautiful views. it took us about 10 min. to see there everything :)

Great landmark to visit and also use as pick up point or meeting point. Nice picture opportunity.. some vendors can be found here offering small local souvenirs.

The present lighthouse, operated by the Sri Lankan Ports Authority, is a 26m high cast iron structure built on Point Utrecht Bastion (Point de Galle) at the southern end of Galle Fort and strategically located in the south west corner of Sri Lanka to guard the shipping lane approach up to Colombo Port. Painted white, it is an elegant structure overlooking Galle Harbour, a major landmark and a popular tourist attraction. Surrounded by coconut palms, it is very photogenic, although it was clad in scaffolding when we were there, presumably for a new coat of paint. The lighthouse at Galle Fort is the oldest light station in Sri Lanka and it is still working.

I was really looking forward to getting a good photo in front of the scenic Galle Fort Lighthouse, but unfortunately it is currently hidden under a bunch of scaffolding (as of March 6th) which does detract from it quite a bit. All the same, it is a nice site to take in as you stroll along the Galle Fort walls. Very busy throughout the day, consistent flow of tourists. still operational and now made electronic the lighthouse is the original 1863 one .. the beach in the front is nice   ..
Unmissable on a walk around the ramparts, very photogenic at different times of day. Views from the lighthouse across the bay are stunning.
Nice view.. which is a stone away from any accomodation at the fort. Nothing special about it honestly , still it will be along the path alomg fort stroll
The fort experience was good as it is build near the sea and other side cricket ground view was nice. Lighthouse is an old one and nothing so different about it.

I Like lighthouses and I found interesting to SEE one in Sri Lanka. The area is a bit touristy but beautiful. Walk around and discover elements of the fortress like this or the Dutch church from 14th century. Very informative.
It's just a small lighthouse, not very ancient as well. Marks the beginning of visitor's walk around the Galle fortifications, so everyone starts from here.
I went for a breakfast buffet for this hotel. It had good verity of foods. Servings were good and fast.
Lovely visit. Difficult getting a stroller around though. Nice to walk around and enjoy the sights! ☺️

One of the iconic places in Galle which represents its rich history. This place is suited for photography preferable sunrise or sunset. Best to avoid during afternoon because of sun and humidity. The downside is that this place is full of tourists which can become sometimes irritating.

This lighthouse is one of the main landmarks in Galle Fort, and one of a few working lighthouses in Sri Lanka.  It is built on the mainland inside the Fort's walls with a beautiful view of the sea around.  It was rebuilt after a fire in the 1940's and its white structure is always featured on postcards and adverts for Sri Lanka.
I wish v could go on the top , the spot is quite crowded with locals swimming n wading in the water. worth a visit.
Lighthouse itself is really nice but what is most amazing are surroundings and especially the wall around the city.

This lighthouse is easy to find located on the Galle Fort Wall. You can get some really nice pictures at sunset and sunrise. Often locals playing soccer and theres a really nice relaxed feel about the area.
The area around the Lighthouse is good for a stroll. And the view of the sunset from this area is quite breath taking.

The Galle Fort Lighthouse is a must if you're in the Galle Fort area. It's the oldest light station in Sri Lanka and is emblematic of the history of commerce in Sri Lanka. At the end of the day, it's just a picturesque lighthouse so certainly don't go out of your way to solely see the lighthouse. Enjoy the restaurants, spas, and shops of the Galle area and check this lighthouse off your list as you spend an afternoon watching the Ceylon sun set.

Ok - it's just a lighthouse, built by the British in 1939, but it is location affords fabulous views across Galle harbour. On it's own it may be nothing that special, but when considered with the views and in the context of the old fortified city it's well worth a look!

The lighthouse somehow completes the impressive and Tsunami-repelling ramparts in Galle and must feature in all visitors' photo collections. It's hard to get a decent shot, however, with all the electrical cables, tourist vans, tuk tuks and pedestrians around, but patience is rewarded.
It's only a few minutes walk from the fort. I am not sure whether you can go inside, but the view outside it beautiful

You can't go inside the lighthouse, at least from what I know. But it's good to include in some pics for the holiday album. I saw it during the day and also at sunset, when it was turned on. I much preferred it then, when it made me think of times past and the history of Galle. Very evocative!
This is a plane old lighthouse that's next to the fort. Best time to visit would be sunset or sunrise and take a photo from the opposite side of the fort with the lighthouse in the background.
The light house was so beautiful and the structure of the galle fort was awesome and the area was so friendly

We took tuk tuk from Unawatuna and went to Galle fort (half day trip) Its a very beautiful place with Dutch taste We couldnt enter the light house i dont know if its permenantly not allowed or just that day which we were been there!!! You can take plenty of beautiful photos and have a yummy food at Galle fort and do shopping as well:))) I do highly recommend to visit Galle fort at least twice :))))
it's an old and historical lighthouse located on a small cliff , with many restaurants and shops nearby , it's a nice place to visit while touring galle fort.
Obviously this is someplace to enjoy at night. In fact, the whole fort is best seen in the cool of the evening. The lighthouse is visible from many of the hotels and restaurants in the fort.
The lighthouse is more of a landmark here i guess... Not much to see or do here. The viewpoint is nice and you can but wooden elephants close by... Not that fun nor interesting.

It's a famous landmark of Galle fortifications which still guides the ships nearby. It's a tall structure on a little cliff. The public is not allowed inside. There is a small beach behind, the only beach in Galle fort. There are a lot of shops and restaurants nearby.

A historical place with great views and a lovely beach, this light house still works and has been maintained well. Very important to watch over youngsters because this structure is build over a wall which looks like a cliff. Please watch your step.
Magical place in the evening to see this old lighthouse still warning ships of danger from the reef close by the shores.
This a great place to stop for a few stunning photos.  It doesn't take long at this stop as there isn't much else to do here.
this is located in the tip of Galle fort . It is a tall structure on a slightly elevated place and a famous landmark of Galle

It is just a lighthouse as you would find anywhere else in the world. It is said that original lighthouse was destroyed sometime back and this is a rebuilt version. You can take couple of pics around it but not allowed to go inside.

If you are not familiar to this area be careful who you are talking to. If you want visit the light house you have to take a boat ride to it. Also you can have nice sea bath after climbing the tower in caved like area as it is very shallow. Take your own food and drink if you plan to stay in the Island as there are no shops in the island (specially beer :-) ).

Lighthouses are always a nice attraction, but there is really nothing special about this one.  The original was burned in 1936 (when kerosene was still used to produce the light) and the current structure was build in 1938.  Good for a photo or two, but that's it.  As far as I know, visitors are not allowed to climb to the top.
Its just a photo spot & you just need to get down on your way after visit to fort or old town. wouldnt take more than 10 min to just go around the placce & click some snaps
Nice point to stop by when viewing the city walls, plenty of other great sights around the Galle fortress

The lighthouse is a full functioning lighthouse guiding the ships and boats passing by Sri Lanka via the Indian Ocean. Not possible to go up but still worth the visit as it is part of the world historical site of Galle.

Not really sure what all the fuss is about... it is simply a light house on the sea front area in galle fort... great for a picture or two but otherwise boring! (Probably has some historical value which may be interesting?)
The lighthouse is the same as most other lighthouses and for some reason reminded me of the lighthouse near Fort Jesus in  Mombassa

Took a scooter ride from Hikkaduwa to Galle with friends and had a great time. The lighthouse was cool and I shot it from all angles. Some nice views in and around the area with nice local residence intermingling with the tourist.

Yes, that is about all one can say about it as all we could do was walk around it and take a photo. I am sure that if the ability to actually go inside the lighthouse then it would be fascinating as that is something I have never done. Perhaps I was there on the wrong day or at the wrong time. Never mind, it did make a nice photo as a memory of Galle.
Not really a big thing "to do", but it's nice to have a walk in the area and around the fortifications. Good place for photos.
The Galle Lighthouse is a 'must see' attraction in Galle - both during the day and at night when its looms of light spread over the town, as well as out to sea of course.
It towers above everything and radiates history. We walked on the walls a bit. Lovely views and  a sense of wonder that all lighthouses have.
We were here for a short visit and there was nothing much to see. Just a lighthouse on the fort with some good views, that's it. Would not mind skipping it if I ever return to Galle

This is beautiful historic lighthouse offers a great view from all sides for good photography. Sunsets are a delight to watch from here. Dont forget to watch crazy jumpers who dives straight down in ocean from cliff. Delighted to visit this place.

indeed just another lighthouse surrounded by stately palms overlooking the turquoise sea.  A great example of Britain"s Imperial lights, it is fully operational with it's fresnel lens rotating.  There seems to be a light keeper, but surely the light has been automated.  No visits to the top.

Situated on the corner of a promontary along the fort walls, the lighthouse stand isolated. Painted white in line with the local buildings and not much taller than the adjacent palm trees it is a stand out building.
Just a lighthouse,but very attractive building. you cant enter unfortunately. Great place to get photos, especially sunset time. Full with tourists.

The lighthouse holds and impressive position at the fort, but at the end of the day its still a lighthouse. Nothing really attractive to go there specifically to visit can be enjoyed as part of visiting the fort in general.
Great spot to watch the sunset, and a very nice place to stroll. Look out for "Crazy Midas" who does a wild dive into the ocean, well worth watching.
Beautiful place in sunset, but cannot enter the lighthouse when we visited. One of the must-sees in Galle Fort.
This is one of the highlights of the tour. You can get the best pictures of this place from every corner.
beautiful lighthouse with hilarious beach. full of tourists & local people but joyful. also getting great scenery. that good
It is a just an average looking lighthouse. But in the evenings, the whole set-up looks amazing against the backdrop of a setting sun.
Nothing special here (about from the accompanying swaying palm trees, blue skies and tropical paradise vibes :) makes for good pics though!
In the near if the Lighthouse is a nice beach to take a bath at a hot summer day. There you can have a nice view over the fort and the sea.
Awesome site to have a look at whilst exploring the old city. Can't go Inside but still a nice view.

After a tiring day in Galle, we went there to watch the sunset. Amazing it is. Water is so clean (there is no beach). Few people swim there as well. The place is crowded. Make sure you get a good seat for the view.

While you're in the area, the lighthouse is worth a look. There isn't much to really commend the lighthouse and, as far as I could tell, there wasn't much history on display to provide context or background. Still, quite pretty to look at. Right next to the lighthouse on the eastern side is a pretty little strip of tranquil water, emerald and blue, that looks very family friendly. Good atmosphere and nice views over to the Japanese pagoda in the distance.
The Lighthouse is a lovely spot to arrive at after spending time walking around the fort and wider area. It offers stunning views of the old city, Fort and the beach.
A nice sunset view, stroll around the place and get soaked amidst the Dutch era landscape is what you get when you visit this old port city
At a corner of the rampart walk, special at night time. Golden beach close by but pick your area carefully as a lot of rubbish is on part of the beach

The Galle Fort Lighthouse is synonymous with Galle Fort and is walking distance from the latter. However my driver drove me there after we finished with Galle Fort given the rising heat. He parked a short distance away and I climbed the steps to walk along the elevated pathway to the Lighthouse. As expected it occupies a prominent spot on the headland overlooking the beautiful Indian Ocean. A small security detail was present at the bottom of the Lighthouse. Good photo opportunities of both The Indian Ocean and The Old Town.
Nice place to visit and know about its history, sea is rough lot of rocks. Overall a one time visit.

We found the place very nice. We started our tour of the fort around 4pm. the sunset is around 6pm. we started from rampart street and reached the lighthouse at a very leisurely pace around 5pm. the light was great and the whole place is very historic. There were a few people but it wasnt crowded. Should also go for a high-tea at aman galle if you are here.
This is definitely must see in Galle. Nice spot for pictures,  nice view and little beach right under. So if you want to take refreshment in ocean, take swimming suite as well ...

We visited Galle Fort on a stormy day and went to the Lighthouse just before the rain started. Looking up at the whitewashed structure with the heavy clouds around was a mesmerising experience. Great photos as well which look lovely on instagram!

Galle fort lighthouse is a great place for who ever looking for historical sceniries as well as for all other entertainments. The light house gives its light to all over the galle town area with a plesent view. Can find any type of foods, acc, leisures at this fantastic place.

Very interesting area. The lighthouse has become the main focal point, there are other places to see; small beach, restaurants and shops. A vibrant place used by tourists and locals. Well worth a visit.
We visited it during a holiday day (full moon day) and it was packed with locals. Generally ok but looked rather run down and uncared for in my opinion.
Serene and quite place for a weekend... No rush... The lighthouse let's u know the old heritage of srilanka while being ruled by Portuguese and british...

The view from this place is very nice. Many people walking up and down this place, taking pictures and just enjoying what this place has to offer. A perfect place to rest and have a snack while relaxing.
Really enjoyed exploring the fort and lighthouse. Lots of locals were hanging out, enjoying a sunny day. The views were stunning. Check it out!
The walk around the fort up to the light house is a must do if the weather is pleasant. the lighthouse is in good condition.

It  looks like an ordinary light house but one should visit it to see the  sea from there. The walk up to the light house from the wall of the fort is a must to see the sea particularly in the early morning

We walked about the Galle city area before heading off to the Lighthouse Beautiful sights and Dutch architecture. That the day was pleasant helped. Got a sense of deep culture and for photography enthusiasts it's quite the place. We stopped at the lighthouse for the old English style tea. The food was lovely, the service beautiful and the ambience the view breathtaking.
This was a fantastic walk with so much historical detail. Something well worth doing and especially if you dive into the small back streets and explore the little shops
Old lighthouse inside the fort and that is about it. Unfortunately you can go inside to see the views or how it looks
When visiting the Old Dutch Fort the Lighthouse is a must see. Recommend walking along the Fort wall and you will eventually arrive at the Lighthouse

This is an amazing place to relax, after a long walk on the fort. Sundays bit crowded. The light house is having a historical background, when the dutch built this. It reminds the old history when going there. But bit careful, when you go with kinds, so windy and risky slopes. Never forget to visit this, if you visit Galle
Impressive lighthouse, which used to be essential to the shipping in the area. However, that traffic has now moved away to Colombo. The lighthouse should be part of a wider visit to the Dutch fort.

Galle is a quaint charming, well preserved town located within a fort. the lighthouse located near the sea front, easily accessible is worth a visit. unfortunately one cant go inside. the beach near it is clean and one can swim in it.
We came across it on our walk around the Fort. A decent photo opportunity but nothing remarkable in my opinion
Nothing more to see, just a light house. You can walk around and see jewellery stores and restaurants nearby.
This place is a good photo during a walk around the fort walls. The beach below (and around) is not really good for sunbathing but the walk and scenery are nice
Situated st the eastern edge of Galle fort it starts working after dark. Sitting on the wall watching light moving across the dsrk sea some times lighting navy patrol boats is a nice experience.
Very old and still working lighthouse. Great location as its right on the coastline and great photo opportunity - looks good on a gopro lens

It was one of attraction that I planned for, good to visit to see old constriction and ocean view and waves hitting the solid walls of Fort.......light house is elegant looking structure that adds to the beauty.....must visit

It was perhaps the time of the day we landed there. At 10:30 am there were not many people or tourists and so was very peaceful. We could click some nice pictures and then at around mid noon groups of tourists gathered.

Tuesday 6th October and we were in Galle, we entered the old Fort and Town, through one of the gates, directly down the road from the Train Station. We followed the sign post and proceeded to walk down Lighthouse Street, it took less than 10 minutes,  at the end of the street it joined up with Rampart Street. The fort's ramparts and the sea were in front of us. Turning left we could see the lighthouse standing proud above the water's edge. We walked along the ramparts towards the lighthouse. It did not take long to walk around but it was worth seeing as this is one of the landmarks of the Old Town and Fort, a World Heritage Centre. When we visited there was an old street seller, near the base of the lighthouse, selling hats.Thee is a small sandy beach near by, good views.
One of the main attractions of the small town of Galle is the lighthouse which is adjacent to the Galle Fort. The Lighthouse is huge and one can spend ample time trying to get that perfect shot!
A well preserved historic site, which is accessed through the fort. One can't enter the place, but the surroundings are also good.
A nice old sightseeing place to visit if ur staying inside the fort enjoying a walk by night its very historical and cool

Unfortunately this lighthouse is absolutely needed but has failed in its function of safeguarding mariners for a couple of reasons.  First it burned down and had to be completely rebuilt in 1936.  Second, many ships have wrecked on the nearby rocks.  Besides that, though, it is a really cool lighthouse.  Take a walk around it and gaze out to sea enjoying the cooling breezes on a hot day.
Kids wanted to see this. So we walked and took photos en route. Its something to walk past and take in as you walk around Galle. You wouldn't spend a huge amount of time here.

There's not much to say about the lighthouse other than that it's there. You can't go into it so it's really just a landmark. There's a little beach at the base of it which is nice to dip your toes into but if you're after a beach holiday - it's not that beach.
Notable white landmark in Galle - you can climb on the ramparts here for a view and good photo opportunity both with the lighthouse and looking out to sea
Nice to look at but that's about it, maybe a photo or two but nothing else. Just include it on a ride past it.
The lighthouse i nice to look at but you can't actually go inside it.  It is (obviosuly) right at the southern-most point of the fort.
please dont miss out on the sun rise and sun set from this light house, you can also catch kids jumping from the fort into the waters. very relaxing place
While walking around the fort, you can't miss the lighthouse. Did not go inside though, just took some photos with it , nothing spectacular!
This easy-to-spot landmark makes a good spot for a group photo while you are exploring the Galle fort.  The views out over the ocean are great and you can get up onto the ramparts here.
Walk down to the fort area and you can't miss this lighthouse, its white and gorgeous next to the palm trees. Makes a good photo!
very popular with tourists and locals alike, picturesque and well kept, makes for beautiful photos and even has a little beach side beneath, pick nick areas stretching to both sides
This is on the fort wall as you walk along viewing the sea. There are steps going down to the small strip of beach from here.
We love walking around the lighthouse, locals and foreigners were all mingling together and gathered in the nearby fort to watch the sunset.

Went down for sunset. Really lovely to see the tourists and locals mi'ngling at this time of day. Young children in the sea or playing cricket. View from the fortifications beautiful and many photo opportunities. Not too many street vendors:ice cream man, a lady selling friendship racemets for 100 rupees and a man selling masks and beautifully crafted wooden boats. No hard sell at all. Will go back during our stay.

And there was me thinking there were no lighthouses in Sri Lanka. 18mts high this one stands and is great to have a look when you are walking around the fort. A nice place for a photo op and there is a little stall to buy some trinkets, definitely bargain though.
Loved walking around the walls of the historic fort (lighthouse is part of the walk). Great place to watch the sunset.

One of the old colonial era remnants - It is indeed a great spot to visit if you have time as you can get some very beautiful pictures here but then again; Sri Lanka is filled with such beautiful picturesque spots. Personally I don't think if you are missing anything; there is just so much more to do in Sri Lanka but do visit it if it is on your way and if you have time.
beautifully built and still working very well to navigate pass by vessels. nice spot for photography especially in early evening

Galle Lighthouse is well-known attraction for tourists, you can see it from afar. It is about 26 m high and its strategic position - at the southern piece of cape. This position has a great advantage  to see any ship, yacht or boat that sails into the harbor from here. Intersting fact is that this is the second lighthouse - the original one was bulit in 1848 and was 24 m high, unfortunately it was destroyed by fire in 1934. The present lighthouse was built in 1939. This is an important part of the tour of the historic city of Galle and you can enjoy you can enjoy a breathtaking view of the ocean.

Got a great view of the ocean and the old town from this viewing point. The seabreeze was quite strong and the sun was intense. Put sunscreen and shades and secure loose clothings before heading here. Easy walk along the fort wall from the entrance along the seashore to reach this lighthouse.

Certainly a must have for every tourist coming into this area...  small streets with one shop and restaurant next to each other offer a cozy atmosphere to stroll around and look at the local products and food and drinks on offer. The view from the light house is wonderful and will provide long lasting memories
Beautifully situated by the sea and the Fort. It did helped us to find our way back to the hotel too. follow the light!

What a wonderful Landmark and place to visit. There are a lot of people about trying to sell you local wares so do be aware of this. Some beautiful views and can get your camera out, although you cannot go inside the lighthouse. If you are earlier enough in the morning you could see the fishermen on their stilts. Lots of shops and place to eat and drink in the nearby dutch hospital.
loved our stay here, you will love the walk around the fort, lovely and quiet with hardly any traffic, great restaurants
A beautiful lighthouse, with access through the fort. The views from the lighthouse are beautiful since its amongst the tallest points in Galle. access though can leave you breathless
We were informed that you could bribe the lighthouse keeper to let you in. But we ahd no luck. There is a lovely view but not somewhere to spend alot of time.
The lighthouse is on the southern end of the fort. Its a nice place to see the sun set and spend the evenings. A walk on the fortification along the sea is recommended
best for memory pictures from the alley just going to the Light house, you could combine it with the beautiful mosk nearby

As we were staying in the old town of Galle, we took a walk early in the morning to see the light house, and I have to say, it is very pretty in the early morning light. Of an afternoon as the sun goes down, lots of tourists go there to take photos, and really that's the main thing you'd go to see the light house for, to take some beautiful pictures. It is the jewel in the crown of the fort walls. A must see when in Galle.
It's a calm stroll around the Galle Fort Lighthouse. Make sure to have your caps / sunglasses, as it gets very sunny and hot in the afternoons.
its a nice walk in the fort. plan to spend about an hour or so talking around. on top of the walls or on the side of the road. its a huge tourist attraction .

This was a well famous hotel in sri lanka as its heritage, quality and the service . Room is well comfort with a beautiful bathroom and a bath tub.out side scenery is blue indian ocen and the world famouse galle light house. Really value for money
Should give more information of this place to tourist to know. A bit dirty area from view of lighthouse to beach next to.
Be sure to be here for the sunset. The best place in the city to catch it would be the fort ramparts in front of the lighthouse. The small beach in front of the lighthouse is very overcrowded though.

There's nothing much to do other than take pictures, it is nice towards sunset and it is lovely to see the locals bath at the small beach just next to the lighthouse.  You'll bump into it walking around the Fortifications so it would be churlish not to go and see it.
Nothing great about the lighthouse though since you are in the area, take a couple of photos with the lights house and move on.

The area around the lighthouse always attracts families and children. The large Muslim population in Galle, in particular, appears to appreciate congregating there and enjoying its shade and the lovely views
We enjoyed seeing the lighthouse while walking the perimeter of the Fort. The next evening we walked near it around dusk and it was nice to see it lit up.

It's just a lighthouse, but it's location (on the ramps of the fort) make it a very nice sight. It was build by the English almost twohunderd years ago. There are some palmtrees around it and (if your lucky) a blue sky behind it. No wonder why so many people make a photo. Our opinion: Go for the photo!
I recommend covering the outskirts of the Old Town before you walk through it, this way you can cover off the main attractions and admire their architecture.

Best enjoyed in the cooler part of the day. The walk along the wall is superb. Beware of the male lace sellers as they are asking much more than the ladies further away from the lighthouse. Try to get at least half of what they are asking
Real Landmark! Surranded by the ocean, offers nice view to the surrandibg area. Below the Lighthouse there is a small beach and good fresh juice and fruit vendor! Enjoy it!!
This is a  historical spot to watch those fantastic indian ocean sunsets climb up onto the ramparts and look out to sea you won't be disappointed

The lighthouse is at one end of the walk along the Galle fortification walls. It's a beautiful setting, nothing particularly to "do" there except take photos and enjoy the gorgeous sights! I'd recommend going there around sun set.

Galle Fort is worth a visit and the lighthouse is somehow the center from which you reach the most important points. Normally, you cannot climb the lighthouse, but the view is just as good from below.

We walked along 'the walls' and passed the Lighthouse in the early evening as the sun was about to set. Very scenic! Lots of locals and tourists visiting, the lighthouse light was on and it looked very attractive with the palm trees nearby. A lovely walk even if the lighthouse is not the original.
Nice enough tower but the people trying to sell you things around it will make sure that you don't stay too long for the viewing.

It has been rebuilt by the British after the two earlier wooden ones were burnt down. It has a commanding position on one end of the Fort and great views over two bays. The structure itself is pretty much just a concrete lighthouse.
It is nice to walk on the beach and see the light house. it is lit in the evening and we walked around it. The walk during the day is pleasant too. Yona S.
This is a great stop for a photo of the lighthouse and mosque nearby and paddle on the beach below the ramparts here.
Great place in Galle Fort to visit and enjoy a nice walk and the view. Lots of restaurants and shopping nearby. Small beach area also close to the lighthouse. Would recommend visiting!

The lighthouse overlooks a beach, where tourists and locals alike meet to relax after a warm day in the sun. The lighthouse (obviously) lights up ar night, and it makes a great vantage point for getting orientated in the city!
It is a nice stop in your walk around the rampart.  You can get a nice view of the Flag Rock and also put your feet in the ocean.

We dedicated this day to the Galle Fort and I definitely believe that you need a whole day, if you are the kinds who would want to discover everything from the narrow paths in the shadow of fort walls built first in 1588 by the Portuguese, then extensively fortified by the Dutch during the 17th century to the vibrant cafes and historic museums.The Galle Fort is a world within a world, an experience like no other.
This lighthouse is located at the extreme end of the fort. Unfortunately we weren't allowed to go up.
Located in side the Galle fort and along the beach. You can walk to the place but we were not able to go  up as it was not allowed..

The lighting is very picturesque and worth a visit as you walk around the town. Below the rampart you can watch the people swimming in the small beach at the base. You can also look out over the bay and see the dagboda on the headland opposite, makes for a lovely photo.

. A visit to  the famous 17th century Dutch Fort in Galle (UNESCO World Heritage Site).  If one is interested in the works of Mr Bawa  then free to explore the Light House Hotel, which is a unique design of Mr. Bawa.
It is a nice hangout place for a couple of hours. Beautiful views from the site. Overall a decent experience for a short while. There are a few restaurant and bar options around to chill around.

This is the oldest active lighthouse in Sri Lanka. Built by the British in 1848 and rebuilt in 1939 when a fire destroyed the original. At 26.5m high this stone lighthouse isn't hard to miss. The public don't have access to climbing the lighthouse as it is still operational. It is a very photogenic structure with the harbour in the background and its location on the historical fort ramparts. Best time to take photos is around sunset.

The lighthouse is an old beacon protecting passing ships from the rocks and shallow water surrounding the area. You will pass by it while walking the ramparts of the old fort at Galle. Good location for a photo op.
On the walls of the fort, just a light house, guess you have to really like them to get excited about it. Shops in the area are well worth a visit though.
The famous lighthouse is ofcourse just a part of the beautiful cute town of portuguese settlements that lie behind the fort walls. Must visit. Must see. Must stay!
You will come upon the lighthouse when walking the walls - it's worth a quick photo only - and then move on.
Great photographic monument with great views over the Indian Ocean. At sunset this is a popular meeting area for local families as well as tourists and is well worth being there to observe life.
An old majestic  lighthouse on the beach overlooking the sea and quite pretty all by itself . There was a hawker selling icecream which was quite nice
A very picturesque part of old Galle town and Fort with beautiful views. Well worth a vist whilst in the town.
Pleasant walk, the fort is quiet turns walking, inside there are shops and restaurants. very different from the chaos outside.

I couldn't sleep, stayed the the Deco On 44 Hotel, which is awesome, and took a stroll through the gold streets to the lighthouse. It was beautiful at sunrise. I saw a few photogs capturing that magical light, a young family strolling the beach, and the lighthouse standing proud in the rising sun.
Easy to find whilst walking around the old fort, the lighthouse is a famous landmark in Galle and a nice photo opportunity. Worth seeing as part of a day around Galle.
Part of your walk along the bastions.  Typical of its era but worth a photo and a look at turn 180 degrees and snap the mosque.
Built in 1838 and lighting the way into the harbour, you cannot go inside so not much to see but it is a prominent landmark.
Focal point for walks in the old town. Building work prevented close inspection, but location provided good vantage point for Mosque opposite

column7: Capelle aan den IJssel, The Netherlands
column11: You can walk and climb over the walls of the old fortress. The fortress consists some 14 bastions with coral and granite stones over an area of 52 hectares (130 acres). The big walls are mostly build in 1663 by the Dutch and still in a good condition. The panorama over the sea and harbour are very beautiful. At the end of the ramparts there is a lighthouse erected in 1939. Several streets in the city have Dutch names like : Moorse Kramerstraat, Lijnbaanstraat, Zeeburgstraat en Middelpuntstraat.

The lighthouse is inside the Galle fort area.  If you go after dark you will be able to see the lights.  A clock tower is under construction near this area just adjacent the stadium. The light station (also known as Pointe de Galle Light) is within the walls of the ancient Galle Fort, and is operated and maintained by the Sri Lankan Ports Authority. Strategically located at the southern end of the headland, it is in full view of any ships entering Galle harbor. The nearly 27 meters (90 ft) lighthouse is also visible from most of the rampart (protecting Galle fort) that runs along the sea. The lighthouse has some historic significance as the oldest light station in Sri Lanka, dating back to 1848. It may be noted that the original lighthouse built by the British (destroyed by a fire in 1934) was located about 100 meters from the current site and was 3 meters shorter. Although not a worth a separate visit on its own right, it does come with the package while visiting the old town and the ramparts. It is at least a pleasant addition to the landscape with its white structure set amongst the surrounding palms.
